title: "Z with stroke" characters
content:
What are these good for?

- U+01B5 LATIN CAPITAL LETTER Z WITH STROKE
- U+01B6 LATIN SMALL LETTER Z WITH STROKE

I always thought the barred "z" was just a stylistic variant, but since they have Unicode points, do they carry some sort of meaning?
author: nina

comments.content: The barred 'z' is used in transliterating Chechen & Ingush, which are usually written in Cyrillic. The letter represents the sound of 's' in 'pleasure'.

<cite>…just a stylistic variant…</cite>

Just a stylistic variant? Stylistic variance is the best reason to keep making new type!

Strabismus: Thanks! That's useful to know.

<cite>"Stylistic variance is the best reason to keep making new type!"</cite>  
Yeah, but maybe not the best/only reason to add another "z".
I believe the polish z-with-dot (ż) is written as a barred z in some (older) fonts/scripts, sometimes.
